original_statement: About three weeks ago my best friend gets kicked out of her house along with her child and she came to me for help. I gladly accepted her and her child to stay at my home rent free until she is ready to go on. My bestfriend and her husband had a huge falling out. I felt extremely guilty. I allowed her to stay at my house for three weeks now. All she has done for me is take and take from me without ever giving. I figured that she was hurt and not in a good place, so I allowed it. After day in and day out of her not cleaning after herself or her son, not helping around the house, and not being a decent roommate is where I feel like I could have done something.
para_statement: This statement has low confidence of being true at 0.52%. About three weeks ago, my best friend and her child were unexpectedly kicked out of their home, and they turned to me for help. Out of compassion, I welcomed them to stay at my place without any rent until they were ready to move on. My best friend had a significant disagreement with her husband. I couldn’t shake the feeling that I should help. For the past three weeks, I have been accommodating them, but all I've seen is them taking advantage of my hospitality without offering anything in return. I assumed her emotional state was fragile, so I let it slide. However, after enduring her neglect to clean up after herself and her son, not contributing to household tasks, and not behaving as a considerate roommate, I think perhaps I should have taken action earlier.

para_statement: Roughly three weeks ago, my closest friend was suddenly asked to leave her home with her child, and she sought my assistance. Moved by empathy, I opened my home to them at no cost until they were prepared to move on. My friend had a major conflict with her spouse. Even though I felt uneasy, I knew I had to help. Over these weeks, I've provided them shelter, yet I've observed them exploiting my generosity without reciprocation. Assuming she was emotionally vulnerable, I overlooked it. Now, after experiencing her failure to tidy up after herself and her child, not contributing to household chores, and not acting as a respectful housemate, I wonder if I should have addressed it sooner.

original_statement: Two weeks ago, we buried my mother in law. It was a sad day that day. My father had a few tears. My mother had a few more tears. My brothers and sisters all gave me a hug. I gave a speech about her life. She was an accountant. She always went to work with a smile. She always got the job done. She was the best accountant at the company. She had a few kids and a husband. They all loved her. She loved to eat cupcakes. She loved them if they had some sprinkles on them. We celebrated this by having a giant batch of cupcakes made for the burial. We all grabbed a cupcake and threw them into the grave before she was buried.
para_statement: Two weeks back, we laid my mother-in-law to rest. It was understandably a somber occasion. My father shed a few tears, while my mother was more visibly emotional. My siblings all embraced me with comfort. I delivered a speech recounting her life. She was a diligent accountant, always heading to work cheerfully and excelling at her job. At her workplace, she was regarded as the finest accountant. She had a loving family with several children and a devoted husband. Her favorite treat was cupcakes, especially those with sprinkles. To honor her memory, we prepared a large batch of cupcakes for the ceremony. Each of us took a cupcake and placed it into the grave as a tribute before her burial.
